column4: If you have imagemagick installed, you can use the identify command.
Or use GIMP as arfbtwn suggests.
aha, identify shows this: fish 15 - bac + DMSO 1_ch00.tif TIFF 8192x8192 8192x8192+0+0 8-bit PseudoClass 256c 64.01MiB 0.000u 0:00.010
does that say anything about what channels are in the file?
thats what i am trying to figure out
I think it might be - it's saying 8-bit image and 256 colours, which implies greyscale. Indexed colour is unlikely in a TIFF, but I could be wrong. I think you'll just have to open it and find out.
well, grayscale image can also be 8-bit image just with a single channel instead og 3
opening the image also wont tell since the viewer may just apply some colormap...making it impossible to see
aha that gave a lot of info, look: http://pastebin.com/SBiqJbSQ
So it looks like you've got a greyscale image, but it's encoded as RGB with the image data in the Blue channel. Weird.
ohh well, i will treat it as a colorimage then :) perfect. thx
im gonna import in my python script, so ill just deal with it in there
